Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research, RedToL - Phylogenetic and Genomic Approaches to Reconstructing the Red Algal (Rhodophyta) Tree of Life
Award.AbstractNarration:
Last Modified Date: 06/23/09 Last Modified By: rmccourt

Abstract
Red algae (Rhodophyta) are important aquatic primary producers that are one of the most anciently diverged eukaryotic phyla with fossil remains dating back to 1.2 billion years ago. The red algal plastid is widespread in the tree of life as an engine of photosynthesis in microorganisms such as diatoms and red-tide forming dinoflagellates. Red algae are also sources of important human foods such as dulse and sushi wrap and have a multitude of pharmaceutical and industrial applications (e.g., agarose and carrageenans). In spite of their obvious importance, the evolutionary tree of life for red algae is poorly known. The aim of this research is to sample broadly across the major groups of red algae and reconstruct their phylogenetic history. To accomplish the aims of RedToL, the project will: 1) reconstruct a robust phylogeny of 471 red algal species using a combined dataset of 2 nuclear, 4 plastid, and 2 mitochondrial genes, 2) obtain complete sequences for a series of 16 plastid genomes that represent the taxonomic breadth of red algae, 3) make freely available red algal multi-gene and genome data via release to GenBank and a project-specific web site. The RedToL team, which consists of prominent red algal specialists from several generations and who use different methods (from morphology to phylogenomics), will address fundamental questions of red algal evolution and their place in the tree of life.
This grant will support training of undergraduates, graduates, and post-doctoral fellows from underrepresented groups, including three international graduate students. The project results will be published in scientific papers and they will be discussed in two grant-supported summer workshops and two advisory board meetings. The workshops will focus on training students to become the next-generation of red algal taxonomists. The project team will also contribute to outreach efforts through various lectures and a dedicated RedToL website.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Drs. Juan Lopez-Bautista (PI, The University of Alabama UA), Suzanne Fredericq (Co-PI, University of Louisiana at Lafayette) and Max Hommersand (Co-PI, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill) completed a research for the collaborative research, RedToL – Phylogenetic and Genomic Approaches to Reconstructing the Red Algal (Rhodophyta) Tree of Life supported by the program Assembling the Tree of Life. During the funding period, the three research laboratories accomplished worldwide field collection, voucher processing, molecular characterization of red algae, and gene and chloroplast and mitochondrial genome analyses of the red algal orders Halymeniales, Gracilariales, Nemastomatales, Plocamiales, and associated groups of seaweeds. The outcome accomplishments included mentoring undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral training, organization of two summer workshops on red algae, an international red algal symposium during the Phycological Society of America national meeting, a workshop on algal phylogenomic analyses at UA, organization and participation of an annual RedToL meeting of all participants, and integration of the RedToL project into our undergraduate and graduate course works. A seminar series for the Tree of Life has been organized during this project at UA. PI Lopez-Bautista has been the host and organizer of the Southeastern Phycological Colloquy at Dauphin Island Sea Lab, Alabama, a meeting targeting the participation of postdoctoral researchers, graduate and undergraduate students. PI Fredericq co-organized several field courses and biodiversity workshops on red algae in Florida, Panama and Costa Rica.

The algal collection of the UNA Herbarium at UA has been digitized and barcoded (1000 specimens), and is online at www.macroalgae.org. Several websites have been created to increase the visibility and the results of this project through the investigator’s websites that provide information about research opportunities, publications, job opportunities and other news related to the project. Two Facebook pages have been recently created at UA. These web outlets are directed to undergraduate education in botany and biology of algae, A laboratory manual has been produced for the teaching of algal biology at UA. The outreach efforts made by the PI and Co-PIs to expand general knowledge on algal research has included Facebook pages, a laboratory manual, published media, digital media (youtube, twitter, websites, internet databases) as well as local and international TV, radio and newspaper interviews to help spread the word about the NSF Tree of Life program, and on the important role of red algae in our everyday lives.
